data.text: . Contents
Introduction

From April 2008, NHS Employment Check Standards became a requirement in the NHS. Robust identity checks were also enforced using the same identity management standards carried out by an NHS organisation's Registration Authority (RA) to verify an individual's identity before allowing access to NHS Care Records Service (NHS CRS) applications.

Combining these two parallel activities into a single Integrated Identity Management (IIM) process has proven to deliver significant benefits through HR/RA Process Integration and the move to Position Based Access Control (PBAC) both supported by Care Identity Service (CIS) and Electronic Staff Record (ESR) to Care Identity Services (CIS) Interface. A new NHS Employers Identity Checks document was released in April 2019 that we must adhere to.

Integrated Identity Management (IIM) significantly improves access control to NHSCRS systems containing person identifiable information through revised business processes and the introduction of two software applications which have already been implemented at the three sites within MSEFT.
The purpose of this document is to:
Outline the agreed processes that we follow in our organisation to support the ESR-CIS interface ongoing
Support the National Registration Authority Policy which provides the core principles that all organisations should follow.
Highlight the roles and responsibilities in relation to the RA process and explain how this process links into existing policies, practices and systems.
Ensure that there is a robust process in place to manage the issue and control of all Smartcards and that they are used securely
Ensure that staff have a clear understanding of their responsibilities
Care Identity Service (CIS)

This is the registration software to manage NHS CRS access control using Smartcards and facilitate the Interface to ESR. CIS uses electronic forms and digital signatures thereby removing the need for paper based workflow. Access control in CIS is facilitated using NHS CRS Access Control Positions (ACP) defined by the Position Based Access Control (PBAC) Methodology which therefore was a pre- requisite to its implementation.
Electronic Staff Record (ESR)-CIS Interface

This interface is used to link staff records in ESR to user records in NHS CRS in order to remove duplication and to drive access control based on the job that a person holds. HR teams currently update ESR when changes are made regarding an employee's assignment to an established position. Where an ESR position is linked to an NHS CRS Access Control Position, the ESR Interface will be triggered by such changes and will automatically update an individual's access rights to NHS CRS compliant systems to reflect the requirements of their new position or status.
For  example  once  a  person  leaves  the  trust  their  NHS  CRS  access  will  be automatically revoked.
To realise further benefits following implementation of the ESR-CIS interface the three trusts reviewed processes/procedures and explored integration opportunities in relation to:
New starters
Managing change
Leavers
Scope

This policy applies to all Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust employees who utilise Smartcard enabled systems, approve access to these systems and staff who  are  responsible  for  the  issue  and  management  of  Smartcards  within  the MSEFT. This policy also applies to those working at the Trust on an honorary or temporary basis (i.e. locums, bank and agency staff). This will also include any employees who are on secondment to a role that requires access to the system.
Definitions

table_items.text: Access Control Positions (ACP) control the access a user has to a Smartcard enabled system
Care Identity Service (CIS) is the software that enables card creation and Management activities
A government standard for the verifying of a persons identity
Electronic Staff Record (ESR) is the system that manages staff's HR records
The interface that allows ESR and CIS to integrate and share and add information to a person's ESR and Smartcard record
Integrated Identity Management (IIM) is the process of managing a person's identity verification through integrated systems
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is the new organisation formed from the merging of Southend, Mid Essex and Basildon NHS Trusts
NHS Care Records Service (NHS CRS) is the system that holds and manages all the Smartcard enabled NHS applications
The organisation that sits above MSB and provides guidance and regulation to MSB
Position Based Access Control (PBAC) is the creation and management of Smartcard positions based on a person's position they hold within the trust
Personal Identification Number allows a user to access their Smartcard securely

Registration Authority (RA) is the collective term for staff working within Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust who have been authorised to issue Smartcards within the national policies and procedures governing the issue and use of Smartcards.
Service Level Agreement is an agreement between a service provider and a client
A security card which can only be issued following appropriate authorisation and gives relevant access to NHS CRS Applications and software

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Employees

All staff associated with the management or use of a Smartcard to access private and confidential information relating to patients or staff must ensure that they abide by the Trusts  Information  Governance  policies  and  procedures.  In  addition  breaches  of access, inappropriate use of health records or abuse of computer systems may lead to disciplinary measures, bring into question professional registration and possibly result in legal proceedings
Chief Executive
Is  responsible  for  authorising  delegate responsibility  for the  management  of  the Registration Authority via Senior Information Risk Owner (SIRO)
Senior Information Risk Owner (SIRO)/ Board/EMT Accountable Person
Is the person responsible for the implementation and adherence to this policy and subsequent compliance by all staff and also:
Who must report to the Board/EMT annually on RA activity and sign off on the RA IG Toolkit submission;
Ensure that this policy is reviewed and audited bi-annually or when new relevant legislation or NHS regulations are implemented;
Responsible for nominating a deputy to take delegated responsibility for this policy where appropriate.
Registration Authority Manager
Has delegated authority and:
Is responsible for running RA Governance in their organisation

Is responsible for the development of local processes that meet policy and guidance for the creation of digital identities, production of smartcards, assignment of access rights, modifications to access and people, removal of access rights in a timely fashion where there is no business justification for the rights to be retained and certificate renewal and card unlocking
Implements local RA Policy and RA Processes adhering to national guidance and policy
Assign, sponsor and register RA Agents and Sponsors
Train RA Agents and Sponsors and ensuring they are competent to carry out their roles and adhere to policy and process
Facilitates the process for agreeing the organisations access control positions
Is responsible for auditing
Is responsible for ensuring users are compliant with the terms and conditions of Smartcard usage

Verifies user's ID to e-GIF level 3 when users are registered ensuring that all RA roles responsible in the creation of a digital identity are effectively trained to do so and adhere to the identification documentation guidelines from NHS Employers
Ensuring leavers from an organisation have their access rights removed in a timely manner
Responsible for the security of (old) paper based RA records this includes CIS Forms

Ensure all service issues are raised appropriately locally and nationally. The RA Manager should report all RA related security incidents and breaches to the organisation's Risk Management Team, Caldicott Guardian, and Executive Management Team or as indicated by the local Information Governance policy.
Smartcard Users
Are responsible for:
Understanding and abiding by the existing Trust policies regarding the safeguarding of patient information and use of the Smartcard
Taking sufficient care of their Smartcard in order to avoid inappropriate use by other users

Reporting all difficulties with the use of the Smartcard via the IT Helpdesk facility where it will be prioritised and assigned to the appropriate individual for action in accordance with the priorities indicated in the SLA
Signing and complying with the Terms and Conditions of Smartcard use
Alerting their line manager of any non-compliance with the RA policy
To ensure they inform the RA Team immediately should their Smartcard be lost, stolen or misplaced.
Procedure
Providing Smartcards to new starters and existing staff who don't currently have a Smartcard
When an individual has been sent an initial offer letter all new starters are required to attend HR, to produce their ID documents and the relevant new starter forms.

Once this has been completed the HR Staff member will record the identity check details in ESR so that RA Staff can arrange an appointment to take a photograph and issue the member of staff with a Smartcard that can then be associated with their ESR record.
The identity checks must be done in a face to face meeting with the applicant. The list of required ID documents can be found in Appendix

For existing staff their ID check details will already be recorded in ESR following their initial employment at the trust. An appointment will need to be made to take a photograph, issue a Smartcard and associate the Smartcard with the ESR record.
Temporary Access Cards (TAC)

Temporary access cards (TAC) mitigate the risk of Smartcard users not being able to access clinical systems in particular circumstances. They are issued for a set short period of time only to a user who has a verified national digital identity.
New Access Control Position (ACP)

When new Access Control Positions are identified, the RA team will need to determine who requires this access and that the RA Manager is informed by completing a “CIS – Position Creation/Modification” form including details of the access the position provides

Upon receiving authorisation and sign off, the new position will be created, approved and granted in CIS before being downloaded into ESR via the Work structure Administrator URP Submit Request process so that it is available for linking to the ESR record.
Amendment to an existing Access Control Position
The Trust RA Staff will receive a notification to amend an existing Access Control Position via four separate methods:
A request from an existing user/manager
Identification of amendment through the review process
Notification from a supplier that an amendment is required
Trust Acquisitions or Mergers

The process for amendment will follow the authorisation process that has already been established. The request for change will be authorised by the Information Governance Manager and the RA Manager with designated oversight of the RA function and signed off.
Personal Information Management

Due to the ESR-CIS interface being active the Trust will use ESR to automatically inform CIS of any personal detail changes, ensuring that the data is kept up to date in CIS and consistent with ESR. Amendments to the data items below, in ESR, will automatically trigger a message to be sent to CIS for ‘granting' and RA and HR staff within the Trust will ensure that they regularly monitor CIS to accept/reject these changes.
The personal details that are shared with CIS from ESR are:
Title;
Surname;
First name;
Middle name;
NI Number;
Date of Birth.

Changes to an employee's name will require a new Smartcard to be produced by RA Staff. The HR Staff performing this change in ESR must direct the employee to the RA Team so that they can arrange to collect their updated Smartcard.
Note: Once a message from ESR is granted in CIS, the CIS record is locked and can only be changed via ESR.
Automated addition and revocation of NHS CRS Access

When a Trust member of staff has their assignment status (to an ESR position linked to a NHS CRS Access Control Position) changed from an ‘active' status in ESR, a message is sent to CIS via the interface to remove access to NHS CRS applications. This ensures that amendments to NHS CRS access take place in a timely manner, extra resource is not required and Information Governance is greatly enhanced. Active assignment statuses are:
Active assignment;
Acting up;
Internal secondment.
One of the following changes to an assignment status will result in the automatic revocation of NHS CRS Access for the Trust taking place:
Assignment Costing Deletion;
Career Break;
Maternity;
Out on External Secondment – Paid;
Out on External Secondment – Unpaid;
Suspend With Pay;
Widow/Widower;
Active Contingent Assignment;
End/Suspend Assignment;
Suspend No Pay;
Suspend Contingent Assignment;
Terminate Assignment;
Terminate Process Assignment;
Inactive Not Worked.

When a change to an assignment status is done only for HR purposes i.e. missing paperwork, the HR Staff making the change must inform the RA Team in advance so that arrangements can be put in place for continued NHS CRS Access. Choosing an inactive status will revoke the employee's access to NHS CRS systems and if done incorrectly, may pose a clinical risk to patients.
Access by Other agencies/staff not employed by the Trust

The Trust acknowledges that there are some instances where staff cannot have their NCRS application access managed via the ESR-CIS Interface and these staff will need to have their NCRS application access managed via CIS directly. It has been determined that the staff being managed via CIS directly within the Trust will consist of the following groupings:
Temporary or agency staff including locums (non-ESR);
Contractor staff (non-ESR).

The RA team will need to record all details of the access request by ensuring the user completes the relevant RA forms and monitor and review periodically to ensure access is to be renewed or removed.
Available RA Forms:
MSE CIS Create New User
MSE CIS Modify User
MSE CIS Position Assignment Modification
MSE CIS Cancel Smartcard

Where Smartcard access is required by third-party organisations or contractors including General Practices, community pharmacies and independent sector health service providers then a written contract or SLA must be developed and linked to this policy.
Incident reporting

Incidents of RA abuse must be reported immediately by any employee especially where they feel that there is a risk to the health of patients, confidentiality or the Trust's reputation. The RA Agents and RA Manager must be notified immediately. Incidents should also be reported in line with the Trust's Incident Reporting or Whistle Blowing Policies.
Incidents that require reporting include:
Smartcard or application misuse;
Theft or accidental loss of a Smartcard;
Non-compliance of local/national Registration Authority Policy or UK legislation;
Any unauthorised access of NCRS applications;
Any unauthorised alteration of patient data.
Significant events will be escalated to the Caldicott Guardian and Information Governance Manger for further investigation in addition to the HR and IT department.
Disciplinary arrangements
Any incidents which relate to inappropriate conduct or behaviour will be investigated in line with the Trust's Workforce Investigations and Disciplinary Policies.

During a disciplinary investigation it may be necessary to suspend and physically remove an employee's Smartcard. The employee's Line Manager will need to consider the impact on the role of removing access to the system. They must discuss with a senior member of the HR team the impact that this will have and whether any suitable alternative arrangements need to be put in place during the period that the Smartcard is suspended. Any arrangements will be undertaken in line with the Trust's Disciplinary Policy.
Confidentiality

All users issued with a Smartcard must adhere to the NHS Confidentiality Code of Practice (November 2003) and the Data Protection Act (2018) and any Trust policies on Confidentiality, Information Security and the Disclosure of Confidential Information.
Any breaches of confidentiality or misuse of the Smartcard will result in disciplinary action.

Every time an individual accesses an electronic patient record an electronic audit trail is created of who they are, when they accessed information and what actions they performed. Patients are able to request this information.

Anyone trying to access patient information outside of the access rules will trigger an alert report, which will be sent to the Privacy Officer and will reviewed with the Information Governance Manager. The privacy officer will take the appropriate action, which could include informing the patient.
Retention of Data

All data collected in support of this policy is subject to the NHS Records Management: NHS Code of Practice. This will apply to all organisations that have operation agreements in place with the Trust whilst this policy is active.
Provision of Equipment
(Permanently installed or mobile) and availability of RA information

All RA equipment, whether permanently installed or of a portable nature, should be adequately protected in accordance with the Trust's Information Technology Security Policy. RA documentation should not be stored/filed or accessible near mobile RA equipment due to potential breaches of PII and PID and other security issues.

Mobile RA equipment should not be left unattended (eg. in the boot of a car) wherever possible. However if this is unavoidable then no Smartcard should be in proximity to the device in question. When Smartcards are not in use they should be stored securely in a locked location.
Training requirements

To support the RA Managers responsibility to deliver training on Care Identity Service to staff involved in carrying out Registration Authority activities, an e- learning package is available. The e-learning focuses on the application of national RA policy, governance and includes training modules on the use of the Care Identity Service (CIS) application

8.1.1 Following the completion of the relevant e-learning material the trainee must notify the RA Manager or an RA Agent so that this can be documented by the RA Manager in accordance with the latest version of the IG Toolkit. Certificates acquired during E-learning need to be sent to the RA Manager/RA Advanced Agents so that a record can be kept of the training. Members of staff should be trained on the following:
Trust Information Governance and IT Security policies;
NHS Confidentiality Guidelines and Data Protection Act (2018);
Registration Authorities Operational and Process Guidance;
National and Local Registration Authority Policy;
NHS Employers National Identity Checks;
NHS Digital e-learning packages;
National Registration Authority and Smartcard Policy e-learning on ESR;
New GDPR Policy.
8.1.2 No access should be given to RA staff until all training has been completed and certificates sent to the RA Manager or RA Advanced Agents.

8.1.3 Staff's line managers are responsible for ensuring that the appropriate training is undertaken by the user before use of the Smartcard. Training or awareness of policies  and  procedures  should  be  undertaken  as  part  of  the  local  induction process.
Monitoring and audit

This Policy will be reviewed bi-annually or whenever new relevant legislation or NHS regulations are implemented. This Policy may also be reviewed and amended at any time if it is considered that amendments are required to ensure the Policy is up to date and accurate for the Trust.

When you come to your appointment for a Smartcard you will need to provide original copies of either:
2 documents from List One and 1 document from List Two
OR
1 document from List One and 2 documents from List Two.
List One
List of acceptable photographic personal identification:
UK (Channel Islands, Isle of Man or Irish) passport or EU/other nationalities passport
Passport of non-EU nationals, containing UK stamps, a visa or a UK residence permit showing the immigration status of the holder in the UK

UK full or provisional photo0card driving licence (must include paper counterpart); or an EU/other nationalities full photo card driving licence (providing that the person checking is confident that non-UK photo-card driving licences are bona fide)
A national (UK or EU) ID card and/or other valid documentation relating to immigration status and permission to work.
List Two
List of acceptable confirmation of address documents:

Utility bill (gas, water, electricity or phone) or a certificate from a utility supplier confirming the arrangement to pay for the services on pre-payment terms at a fixed address. More than one utility bill may be accepted if these are from two different suppliers and utility bills in joint names are also permissible. (Must be dated within last 6 months)
Local authority tax bill (i.e. council tax). (Must be dated within last 12 months).

UK full or provisional photo-card driving licence (must include paper counterpart): or a full old style driving licence (if not already presented as a personal ID document). Old style provisional driving licences are not acceptable.
Most recent HM Revenue & Customs tax notification (i.e. tax assessment, statement of account, notice of coding). (Must be dated within last 12 months). A P45 or P60 is not acceptable.
Financial statement (e.g. Bank, Building society, store card, credit card or credit union statement) containing current address. (Must be dated within last 6 months)
Mortgage statement from a recognized lender. (Must be dated within last 12 months).
Local council rent card or tenancy agreement. (Must be dated within last 6 months)
Benefit statement, book or card: or original notification letter from the Dept of Work
& Pensions (DWP) confirming rights to benefit (e.g. child allowance, pension). (Must be dated within last 12 months).

If you are unable to provide any acceptable photographic personal identification, then we request two forms of non-photographic personal identification and two documents confirming your address plus a passport-sized photograph of yourself.
